awd_abstract_narration:
This award will fund the 2018 MINDS (Mentoring for Innovative Design Solutions) Workshop organized by Alpha Eta Mu Beta, the National Biomedical Engineering Honors Society. The workshop will be held October 17-20 in Atlanta, GA, in parallel with the BMES 2018 Annual Meeting. This will allow the students selected for the MINDS Scholar Program to also participate in the BMES Annual Meeting. The MINDS Scholar Program is an innovative approach that provides students with the opportunity to collaborate and network with peers and mentors across the country for a 5-month period, while building necessary engineering design skills, including three key considerations that are not usually stressed in coursework projects. The three key considerations are: (1) market considerations for commercialization (unmet need, size of market reimbursement potential, etc.), (2) regulatory strategy, and (3) evaluating prospects for intellectual property protection. The program begins with an initial workshop where students meet their team members, drawn from other universities across the US, and mentors. The team then selects a central design idea that will be developed over the subsequent 5 months. Students will be selected through a competitive process, with junior undergraduates preferred. Students will then work with their teams and mentors to develop a design solution that takes into account issues such as market evaluation, intellectual property issues, and regulation. Subject matter experts will provide support to the teams during this 5 month design period. Teams will be encouraged to submit their designs to various design contests, investment opportunities, and grant programs. This program will develop a core group of engineers who will better understand the importance of considering human needs before attempting to design devices, and who will be more likely to engage in a variety of activities that improve the human condition. Moreover, the participants will learn how to assess human needs and will effectively use the key design considerations that are of paramount importance for successful translation of ideas to the marketplace so that they can truly help people. Additionally, the collaborative and long-distance communication skills that they develop in this project will better equip them to work in an environment that is increasingly dependent on communication between distant facilities and customers. 


The majority of design courses in the US, particularly in biomedical engineering programs, do not have sufficient time to provide students with a strong experience in the non-technical aspects that are key to design success: market potential, intellectual property, and regulation. This program will provide seven teams of three students, selected through a competitive process from across the US, with key experience related to real world design processes for medical systems. It will also provide students with significant experience in working on a geographically separated team and with peers from varied backgrounds, both of which are strongly valued by industry.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Alpha Eta Mu Beta (AHMB) is the international biomedical engineering honor society, which recognizes and encourages excellence in the field of Biomedical Engineering and Bioengineering. AHMB's "Mentoring for INnovative Design Solutions" (MINDS) Scholar Program provides biomedical engineering students with the opportunity to collaborate and network with peers and mentors across the country for a 5-month period, while building necessary engineering design skills not sufficiently emphasized in regular coursework. For instance, (1) market considerations for commercialization (why is this product needed, what market is there for it and how big is this market, etc.), (2) regulatory strategy (what regulations does the product need to meet, and what would be a successful strategy to get the product approved), and (3) evaluating prospects for intellectual property protection (how can the design team protect others from using their idea or copying their product).

 

In order for biomedical engineers to address public healthcare needs, they need to have the knowledge and skills to navigate every step and aspect of bringing a product to market. During the program, MINDS Scholars enhance their knowledge of product design, but they also learn how to effectively communicate with collaborators from other schools and organizations using online tools, which are becoming an increasingly important skill in today's work environment.

 

Participation in the MINDS Scholar Program is through a competitive application process among biomedical engineering majors. Each annual MINDS Scholar Program starts with an in-person workshop, where students meet their team members and mentors, and create an action plan. They select a central design idea that is refined during the 5-month period, and they actively collaborate to advance the project forward, culminating in a final report.

 

In the 2018-2019 program, 20 students completed the program with the guidance of 14 mentors. By the end of the program, participants were able to create a novel product idea, describe how they used the key design considerations in the design process, and state the features, benefits and impacts of their products through production of a promotional presentation. Product ideas varied widely and included a bandage for people with clotting disorders, a device for detection and treatment of retinopathy of prematurity, a device to monitor preeclampsia in pregnant women, an injectable biodegradable polymer for broken rib stabilization and healing, a bed pad to measure vital signs in neonates, an at-home affordable STD testing kit, and a pain-reducing chest drain tube.

 

Students were surveyed at the beginning and end of the program. A majority of students agreed or highly agreed that the MINDS program had improved their perceived skills in understanding the design considerations addressed in the program and applying them to any project, assessing product requirements, explaining key features of a project, communicating technical matters to others, collaborating remotely, and working in a team. Many students also reported that MINDS impacted their career goals. The results of the 2018-2019 program, and feedback from students and mentors, were used to improve the program for future cohorts.

 

Some quotes from 2018-2019 students were as follows:

 

"The MINDS program taught me a lot about a multifaceted approach to biomedical engineering design and communicating with a team over time zones and long distances. I have a much better understanding of what to consider before beginning the design for a product that will improve healthcare. In the future, this will help me save time in my design approach and will allow me to make adjustments to my design decisions around marketing, intellectual property, and regulatory considerations. Additionally, learning how to communicate with a design team over long distances was very beneficial and revealed to me the challenges of organizing meetings over time zones and careers."

 

"The MINDS program allowed me to become a part of all the aspects of the design process, all the way to steps for regulatory and intellectual property. This helped me realize that as an engineer I need to not only make my product work effectively, but also make it so that it complies with the proper standards and regulations."

  

"Prior to MINDS, I was on the pre-med track for sure, but now after having enjoyed coming up with a design for a new product and overall genuinely being curious as to where we can take our design further, I am considering whether industry or grad school may also suit my interests."

 

"I am pursuing a career in medicine, and this program has taught me how to identify gaps in healthcare, and how to work with a design team to use my experience in the medical field and apply it to biomedical research."

 

In summary, we achieved our aims of teaching students how to integrate market needs, regulatory considerations, and intellectual property strategy into the design process. In doing this, we also increased their awareness of how biomedical devices and technologies can benefit society.
